Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Constitutive Relations in Amorphous Metals

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms and constitutive relations in amorphous metals. Amorphous or metallic glass is a structurally disordered solid without the long-range translational order. This topological disorder leads to some of the most remarkable mechanical properties for this class of materials. In the past decade, extensive research and development have been done to harvest the properties, especially the mechanical properties, which led to several constitutive relations. However, these relations suffer from both conceptual difficulties and lack of critical experimental support. In particular, two constitutive models are going to be tested: one is based on Drucker-Prager criterion and transition state theory; and the second, a new theory for plasticity, is the free energy-based approach. Both FEM and atomistic modeling are planned.

The ultimate goal of this research is to establish the constitutive relations among stress, strain, strain rate, temperature, and various physical, structural properties and compositional changes for amorphous solids, which is one of the remaining frontiers in mechanics of materials where no working constitutive model exists to date. This exercise will not only help the scientific community to get closer to more physically justified and working constitutive models for metallic glasses, but will also bring the field a step further toward formulation of deformation in topologically disordered solids in general. Thus this effort is expected to contribute to advancements in the area of mechanics of solids. Associated educational plans will be synergistically integrated with the proposed work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Amorphous alloys, or metallic glasses, are structurally disordered solids without the long-range translational order as seen in crystals. The structural disorder is originated from randomly packed atoms. This so-called topological disorder results in some of the most remarkable mechanical properties that their crystalline counterparts can only envy at: high strength close to the theoretical value, large elastic strain, and high toughness. Metallic glasses cover a wide range of systems including transition, refractory, rare earth metals, and their alloys. These unique and superb properties make them the perfect candidates for many applications including structural components, durable and high performance equipment, coating, and miniature devices subject to large loading, and wearing and corrosive protectors. In addition, they can be produced and shaped much easily and cheaply. In the past decade, extensive research and development have been done to harvest metallic glasses, especially the mechanical properties, which include several constitutive relations.

Although some constitutive models are around, they are limited in many aspects. One is the ad hoc nature of the treatment of the internal variables and the second is the scarcity of experimental support. The difficulties with the existing models come from two sources: One is the lack of a deeper understanding of mechanical properties at atomic scales, and the second is the improper formulation of constitutive models, guided, or rather misguided by the thinking widely accepted in crystalline systems. Therefore, there is an urgent need in developing new and suitable constitutive models.

This proposed research is focused on establishing a new constitutive model for metallic glasses. To do so, we plan to focus on two aspects: one is to rely on extensive atomistic modeling from which we expect to gain deeper and detailed information on atomic mechanisms of deformation, and the second is to carry out theoretical work on establishing new constitutive relations based on the atomic scale information and experimental inputs. In particular, we focus on developing a free energy based constitutive model that treats mechanical deformation as a stress-driven process, rather than a thermally activated transition state process. Thus many difficulties in the current constitutive models are expected to be rectified.

This project is a one year, Early Concept Grants for Exploration Research (EAGER) grant. In this grant period, we performed (1) comparative study of several existing constitutive models for metallic glasses, from which we based our approaches for a new constitutive model and (2) developed and tested the new free energy based constitutive model. Specifically, (1) we performed a systematic study to compare and evaluate several existing constitutive models for metallic glasses; (2) Explored and evaluated these models. For von Mises model, the major deficiency is the lack of consideration of internal state variables such as free volume dilatation; for Coulomb-Mohr model, it is the lack of explicit incorporation of free volume change and ad hoc nature of the frictional coefficient; (3) We tested a Drucker-Prague model which treats the volume dilatation and the conjugate field of pressure in metallic glasses. This model shows that incorporating volume dilatation can indeed accounts for some key observations for deformation in metallic glasses such as shear inclination angle change that the other models cannot.

We also extended our effort to include undergraduate research and teaching. Two undergraduates were working with the PI on independent research. The PI also used the modeling and interactive tools and results from this research in his class, Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering Material Design. The two undergraduate student...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Amorphous alloys, or metallic glasses, are structurally disordered solids without the long-range translational order as seen in crystals. The structural disorder is originated from randomly packed atoms. This so-called topological disorder results in some of the most remarkable mechanical properties that their crystalline counterparts can only envy at: high strength close to the theoretical value, large elastic strain, and high toughness. Metallic glasses cover a wide range of systems including transition, refractory, rare earth metals, and their alloys. These unique and superb properties make them the perfect candidates for many applications including structural components, durable and high performance equipment, coating, and miniature devices subject to large loading, and wearing and corrosive protectors. In addition, they can be produced and shaped much easily and cheaply. In the past decade, extensive research and development have been done to harvest metallic glasses, especially the mechanical properties, which include several constitutive relations. Although some constitutive models are around, they are limited in many aspects. One is the ad hoc nature of the treatment of the internal variables and the second is the scarcity of experimental support. The difficulties with the existing models come from two sources: One is the lack of a deeper understanding of mechanical properties at atomic scales, and the second is the improper formulation of constitutive models, guided, or rather misguided by the thinking widely accepted in crystalline systems. Therefore, there is an urgent need in developing new and suitable constitutive models. This proposed research is focused on establishing a new constitutive model for metallic glasses. To do so, we plan to focus on two aspects: one is to rely on extensive atomistic modeling from which we expect to gain deeper and detailed information on atomic mechanisms of deformation, and the second is to carry out theoretical work on establishing new constitutive relations based on the atomic scale information and experimental inputs. In particular, we focus on developing a free energy based constitutive model that treats mechanical deformation as a stress-driven process, rather than a thermally activated transition state process. Thus many difficulties in the current constitutive models are expected to be rectified. This project is a one year, Early Concept Grants for Exploration Research (EAGER) grant. In this grant period, we performed (1) comparative study of several existing constitutive models for metallic glasses, from which we based our approaches for a new constitutive model and (2) developed and tested the new free energy based constitutive model. Specifically, (1) we performed a systematic study to compare and evaluate several existing constitutive models for metallic glasses; (2) Explored and evaluated these models. For von Mises model, the major deficiency is the lack of consideration of internal state variables such as free volume dilatation; for Coulomb-Mohr model, it is the lack of explicit incorporation of free volume change and ad hoc nature of the frictional coefficient; (3) We tested a Drucker-Prague model which treats the volume dilatation and the conjugate field of pressure in metallic glasses. This model shows that incorporating volume dilatation can indeed accounts for some key observations for deformation in metallic glasses such as shear inclination angle change that the other models cannot. We also extended our effort to include undergraduate research and teaching. Two undergraduates were working with the PI on independent research. The PI also used the modeling and interactive tools and results from this research in his class, Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering Material Design. The two undergraduate students were recruited from the class. Several graduate students were recruited and trained in computational materials science. Undergraduate student...
